Hi, WWT,

I help out here with preliminary gathering of info clarification and answer a few of the more straightforward queries (which often turn out not to be straightforward at all)...

...this theme of sudden loss of connectivity is quite common (although, when you think about the total amount of users, it's actually very small).

I can't help on this except to say that many of the problems with connectivity are due to Third Party software - especially BitDefender - that manifest themselves in various error messages. If you search for similar problems in the search bar, you'll find a lot of suggestions from the forum users.

content: okay - I finally got to the root of the problem. It turns out as of the time my email problem first started that Optus was no longer supporting Thunderbird. After a very prolonged discussion and pointing out that I have been a customer for almost 30 years and pointed out the time I had wasted trying to resolve this problem, they agreed to have there tech team have a look at it ....long story short - they have re-established my connection so I am still able to use Thunderbird....not ideal ...but problem solved for me at least. Thanks for all the support and input.

content:
Thunderbird doesn't have 'Customer Support'. It as open source and donation funded email program. The Community Forum is a group of people who come by and offer advice to people needing help. It's not a good idea to publicise your phone number as just about anyone could ring you and pretend to be someone they're not, even try to get money from you when they're not entitled to it.

The way forward is to post your problem and one of the contributors will, hopefully, respond to your query.
creator: frisée

content:
You could let your Email Provider know. Although they probably won't be able to do very much about it.

Spammers collect email addresses and then include them as the return address in the emails they send out. The body of the email contains the damaging links so the email address is completely superfluous except to try and legitimise it.

In the early days of the Internet, it used to happen to me a lot - but I changed address a few times and don't put my email address on public display for it to be retrieved and used.

content:
martypa said
On 1/17 you asked me to send you a screen shot without email addresses, so I made the screen shot for the main account that's problem less email addresses. When Thunderbird was installed on this computer back around June, it placed all of the folders in each email account under the respective inbox. I asked you to blacken out the email addresses - not remove them. Unfortunately, I can't see where the folders sit in relation to the accounts you have.

The partial structure you've sent look like what I usually encounter when I have to have a Quicklink with the elderly lady I look after. She accidentally click-drags folders all over the place and I have to spend five minutes getting them back into the right place.

I don't know what effect this folder structure would have on functionality but, somehow, it needs to be put back to 'normal'

Each email account should have Inbox, Junk and Trash under them - plus any folders you've made. The Local Folders should have Drafts, Sent, Junk, Trash, Outbox - plus any self-made folders. This is how it is with a POP3 account. None of these folders should be inside one another.

content:
My initial reply was this:

A new calendar duplicates the old calendar initially which makes it easier to split one calendar into two. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1410277 sfhowes said "On the Calendar tab, enable Find Events under Events & Tasks, choose All Events on the filter drop-down, select the events, then Delete key."

This would have caused the new calendar to become blank. However, I've been playing around with my own calendar and it may be that the two calendars remain linked as when I changed one entry in one calendar, it changed it in the other.

I would test what happens with the second calendar and the impact it has on the first before trying to delete all entries.

creator: frisée

content:
"If you do a search in the c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles folder, you may find abook.sqlite and history.sqlite. These are the technical filenames of the addresssbook and the collected addressbook. You can import them with tools>import>importfromafile. This sometimes happens, that thunderbird creates a new profile and some content is left behind. No, this does not happen to everyone and is likely a glitch wherein an update was interrupted by another program, such as an antivirus product."

This might help. search for "abook.sqlite". Found it in a file, C:/windows.old. look for last oldest.

content:
Hi frisée,

thank you for you reply.

frisée said
If you have cancelled the contract with A, surely company A will have deleted your email account with them? So how would you be able to access these emails?

Surely, the emails that were synced last time there still was a connection to the server are still on my computer. Why else would there be a 500+ MB directory? But when I want to look at them in Thunderbird I am blocked by the password prompt. Even if I cancel it, the overview list that should show the mails stays empty.

If your contract doesn't exist (as above my first point) what would you lose by deleting that account from Thunderbird and, therefore, it's ability to attempt to retrieve email?

I am pretty sure that removing the account from Thunderbird would irrevocably delete my mails from my computer. The very emails I wish to access.

You could, alternatively, switch off automatic email retrieval under the server settings.

I have already switched off any checkbox concerning updating of mails I found. Still, as soon as I select the Inbox, it asks for my password. I assume that the checkboxes only passive retrieval so I can get notifications while Thunderbird runs in the background. But as soon as I actively access any of the folders, it tries to sync.

---

My question now is: Is there some hidden feature that makes it possible to view the (old) mails nonetheless? If not, could it be added? Or is there a way to move all the mail to another account on the file system level? Do I have to do something specific, so that Thunderbird does not break or delete anything?
creator: sideboard

content:
You are talking about an IMAP account?

Thunderbird (unless you program it to - or you make a copy of emails in a Local Folder) only mirrors what's on the main Email Server on the Web. If you delete the account in TB, it doesn't effect the emails on the Mail Server - but if you delete a Mail Server, TB can't mirror what isn't there.

A POP3 account is different.

It's usual to set it up so that all emails are downloaded into the computer, held by TB and deleted from the Mail Server. So, ending an account with an Email Provider would do nothing to the copies of the emails that are held in TB.

Now that's been sorted, we can deal with any other matter that needs to be dealt with. The query has become rather fragmented and I'm not completely sure what's outstanding. You can respond here with a revised query for anyone to answer who feels they can respond. Or begin a new thread. But it's probably best to add the post under this response.

Certainly, TB will continue to try and sync with an Email Account if you haven't deleted the account - but you don't wish to do that at this time. I would have thought that turning off automatic-sync would have prevented that action but it appears not.
creator: frisée

"How can I access my old mails? Can I somehow move or import them to account B?"
creator: sideboard

content:
Oh dear. You put 'local' in the introductory header and not in the body of the problem. No wonder I'm seeing a different problem than the one it actually is!

And the answer is still, if you have deleted the old account, the data has been deleted. Even if it was saved in a local folder.

You could go to C:\Users\[Users]\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\XXXX.default-release and look to see if there are any 'Local Folders' that have been left behind after your deletion of the account. I don't run IMAP so my Local Folders are under 'Mail' - they may be there also even in IMAP but I'd try the IMAPMail folder, too.

If there are local folders unassigned to a profile then they can quite easily be added to an email profile - but I am only confident to do that in a POP3 account so I can't help you.
creator: frisée

content:
You can switch Thunderbird to offline mode. You have multiple options:

  1. Use the main menu bar: File (Alt-F) > Offline > Work Offline.
  2. Click the network status icon: Look for the icon in the bottom left corner of the Thunderbird window and click it to toggle offline mode.

Once in offline mode, this should allow access to your messages, assuming they have been downloaded for offline use while the IMAP server was still available.

You could easily have avoided the entire hassle if you had copied your messages to the Local Folders account prior to moving to the new provider.
creator: christ1

content:
In case this helps to clarify the issue here for anyone reading this, what the OP is trying to accomplish is to preserve the copy of the messages that Thunderbird still keeps locally on the computer for this account. Even though it was an IMAP account, Thunderbird would (depending on the settings) keep a local copy of the messages, mainly so the account may also be used offline.

As a result of the account no longer being active, Thunderbird can no longer synchronise with the server, but that wouldn't cause any harm to the local copy of the messages kept by Thunderbird. It's just as if Thunderbird had gone permanently offline for that account, except for the fact that Thunderbird may keep trying to connect to the server, which is annoying.

So that local copy of the messages that no longer exist on the server but do still exist within the account folder in the profile folder, is what the OP wants to get access to without Thunderbird trying (and failing) to connect to the server every time he does.

Now, to answer one of the questions asked, not saying this would be the preferred way to deal with it:

is there a way to move all the mail to another account on the file system level?

IMAP mail is stored within a folder called after the IMAP server, located within the ImapMail folder in the profile folder, which can be found as described here:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data

Copying the mbox files (text files in mbox format without filename extension) to a location within Mail > Local Folders in the profile folder should in theory cause Thunderbird to show them as local folders the next time it is launched.

Always make a backup of the profile folder before manipulating its contents at the filesystem level, just in case.
creator: DavidGG

content:
Firstly, if there are 10 calendars then it's because you chose to do that - whether accidentally or not. They didn't occur by TB automatically creating them without your input.

I don't know of a way to merge all your calendars - I've looked at the database and the matter doesn't appear to have come up. I'm a little confused by your use of 'tasks' and 'events' - you seem to use the words interchangeably but these are different inputs in TB and are dealt with differently.

If I was in your position, I would start from scratch with a new Calendar and input events one by one into that new one, deleting the events from the old calendar until nothing was left. Then delete the old calendar. And so on to the next.

Or maybe start with the most populated calendar and and to that? I don't know...

However, if you have *thousands* of events, I wonder whether a single calendar is really the way to go? The 'Today Pane' in the Email interface would be so cluttered as to make it almost impractical. And then you have to add your tasks to it.

You will have to decide how easy you want access to be - but a clean up of the multiple calendars would certainly seem to be the best way to go.

Oh, and before I did anything, I would be *at the least* saving copies of each calendar to an external source (right click on the calendar name and 'Export') in case something went horribly wrong.

.oOo.

Tout d'abord, s'il y a 10 calendriers, c'est parce que vous avez choisi de le faire, que ce soit par accident ou non. Ils ne sont pas apparus parce que TB les a créés automatiquement sans votre intervention.

Je ne connais pas de moyen de fusionner tous vos calendriers. J'ai regardé la base de données et le problème ne semble pas avoir été soulevé. Je suis un peu dérouté par votre utilisation de « tâches » et d'« événements ». Vous semblez utiliser les mots de manière interchangeable, mais ce sont des entrées différentes dans TB et elles sont traitées différemment.

Si j'étais à votre place, je recommencerais à zéro avec un nouveau calendrier et j'insèrerais les événements un par un dans ce nouveau calendrier, en supprimant les événements de l'ancien calendrier jusqu'à ce qu'il ne reste plus rien. Puis je supprimerais l'ancien calendrier. Et ainsi de suite jusqu'au suivant.

Ou peut-être commencer par le calendrier le plus rempli et ainsi de suite ? Je ne sais pas...

Cependant, si vous avez des *milliers* d'événements, je me demande si un seul calendrier est vraiment la voie à suivre ? Le « volet Aujourd'hui » de l'interface de messagerie serait tellement encombré qu'il serait presque impossible à utiliser. Et puis, vous devez y ajouter vos tâches.

Vous devrez décider du degré de facilité d'accès que vous souhaitez, mais un nettoyage des différents calendriers semble certainement être la meilleure solution.

Oh, et avant de faire quoi que ce soit, j'enregistrerais *au moins* des copies de chaque calendrier sur une source externe (clic droit sur le nom du calendrier et « Exporter ») au cas où quelque chose se passerait mal.
creator: frisée

content: U maakt waarschijnlijk gebruik van het IMAP-protocol, wat prima is. Dit is een synchronisatieprotocol dat er voor zorgt dat al uw gekoppelde apparaten hetzelfde te zien krijgen. Het klopt dus dat als u in Thunderbird van de pc een bericht verwijderd, dat dat ook uit beeld verdwijnt in Thunderbird op de laptop en vice versa. Deze koppeling is allen te verbreken door de pc niet meer aan het internet te hangen, zodat er niet meer wordt gesynchroniseerd. Echter als u alle bestanden van de pc verwijdert, bijvoorbeeld door de pc te wipen of bestanden in de prullenbak te gooien, dan zal er geen 'signaal' van Thunderbird naar de mailserver worden gestuurd om alle mail weg te gooien. De mail blijft dus gewoon bestaan en beschikbaar op de laptop. Hopelijk is het zo duidelijk.

content:
You have two error messages. First, TB requires you to enter your password for the OUTGOING MAIL server, called the SMTP Server. Second, when you enter your password (I assume), the SMTP (OUTGOING) server times out. Nothing here indicates that you are having trouble with receiving email.

1. Check your SMTP Password Checking passwords can be done by accessing the Hamburger icon (top right)/Settings/Search for 'Password'/Saved Passwords/Show Passwords (use your windows log in to access the information). You need to find the smtp entry and check/change that entry. I would delete the value it has and re-enter it. Then, try retrieving your email again. If that still doesn't work:

2. SMTP Server timing out If you search for the string "the connection to the outgoing server SMTP timed out" in the top right search field, there will be numerous articles with information about how to resolve this issue. The most common solution is that Anti-Virus software needs to be switched off from scanning emails. If the solutions offered don't work, please reply to the post and it will be relisted as in need of a solution.

.oOo.

Vous avez deux messages d'erreur. Tout d'abord, TB vous demande de saisir votre mot de passe pour le serveur de COURRIER SORTANT, appelé serveur SMTP. Ensuite, lorsque vous saisissez votre mot de passe (je suppose), le serveur SMTP (SORTANT) expire. Rien ici n'indique que vous rencontrez des problèmes de réception de courrier électronique.

1. Vérifiez votre mot de passe SMTP La vérification des mots de passe peut être effectuée en accédant à l'icône Hamburger (en haut à droite)/Paramètres/Rechercher « Mot de passe »/Mots de passe enregistrés/Afficher les mots de passe (utilisez votre connexion Windows pour accéder aux informations). Vous devez trouver l'entrée SMTP et vérifier/modifier cette entrée. Je supprimerais la valeur qu'elle contient et la saisirais à nouveau. Ensuite, essayez de récupérer à nouveau votre courrier électronique. Si cela ne fonctionne toujours pas :

2. Expiration du délai d'attente du serveur SMTP Si vous recherchez la chaîne « the connection to the outgoing server SMTP timed out » dans le champ de recherche en haut à droite, de nombreux articles contenant des informations sur la manière de résoudre ce problème s'afficheront. La solution la plus courante consiste à désactiver le logiciel antivirus pour analyser les e-mails. Si les solutions proposées ne fonctionnent pas, veuillez répondre au message et il sera répertorié comme nécessitant une solution.

content:
re :Using the config editor, I set mailnews.default_view_flags to "0" (unthreaded). (See 1st screenshot.)

Screenshot does not show : 'mailnews.default_view_flags' to "0" - it is set to 1 It's the one at the bottom of the list in the image you posted. But 'mailnews.default_news_view_flags' does show it is set to "0"

It seems you have not set the required 'mailnews.default_view_flags to "0" So please repeat the process below

  • Settings > General
  • Scroll to bottom
  • click on 'Config Editor' button - It opens in a new tab
  • In search type: default_view
  • You will see this line: mailnews.default_view_flags - It will have a numerical value of 1
  • click on the 'pencil' icon on the right to allow an edit.
  • Remove the number 1 and type in a zero 0
  • click on the 'tick' icon to save your settings.

You will now have: mailnews.default_view_flags - It will have a numerical value of 0 This will now mean any new folders you create, they will not have threading by default.

I have created some images which will help you to see what is required before you do it and help you step by step all the way.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
I'm confused why you say that "Screenshot does not show : 'mailnews.default_view_flags' to "0" - it is set to 1". I just checked the screenshot and my accounts setting in the config editor and it IS set to 0. Please clarify.

Thanks for your help.
creator: queenmab100

content:
Queenmab100 said
I'm confused why you say that "Screenshot does not show : 'mailnews.default_view_flags' to "0" - it is set to 1". I just checked the screenshot and my accounts setting in the config editor and it IS set to 0. Please clarify. Thanks for your help.

OK - lets try again - you are not looking at the 'mailnews.default_view_flags' preference and your image is very clearly saying you have altered some things, but not the one you need to alter.

I have copied the image you posted and display it below. I said look at the last item in the displayed list - so I have put a red outline around the last item displayed in your image. It says: 'mailnews.default_view_flags' = 1 It is not set using bold font so means you have not altered it. It is still using the default = 1. There is also no reset to default icon on the far right. You need to set it to 0.

However, you have edited 'mailnews.default_news_view_flags' (3rd item in list) because that is set to 0. It is in bold font and has a reset to default icon on far right, so I know it is not using the default, it has been altered to use 0.

content:
Don't you just love Windows Updates, huh? I advise all the users I watch over to back up their data files once every week to an external HD to safeguard against this sort of thing. That would be a good idea to start asap.

Also, was TB open and running when you were dealing with the Windows Update? If it *wasn't* then that makes the interference weird. Again, having no background Apps running when updating Windows is a good safeguard.

It may be that all TB needs is for the folders to be repaired. Probably start with that. Go to an affected folder and right click, then 'properties' and select 'repair'. Do it for one or two and see if it manages to sort the problem out.

Before you do that, however, to make sure no data files are changed by any actions that are attempted to repair this, save all your profile folders located at C:\Users\[Users]\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\XXXX.default-release to somewhere external to the computer itself. Then we have something to go back to.

content:
Ak máte ešte prístup k starému Thunderbirdu s poštou, tak odporúčam tento postup: Zo starého PROFILU Thunderbirdu prekopírujte do nového PROFILU Thunderbirdu celý priečinok Mail (Ak mate prístup POP3) a priečinok ImapMail (ak mate prístup IMAP). Tam je všetko to čo potrebujete - všetka pošta a nastavenie účtov. Takto mate teraz skopírovanú poštu a nastavenia účtov. Pokiaľ spustite Thunderbird, tak uvidíte späť svoju starú poštu. C:\Users\<Windows user name>\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\<Profile name>\ http://kb.mozillazine.org/Profile_folder_-_Thunderbird#Windows_Vista.2C_7.2C_8.1_and_10

K spokojnosti teraz chýbajú iba KONTAKTY Cez vebové rohranie sa prihláste k svojmu emailu. Tu si exportujte svoje kontakty do napr: *.csv súboru. V Thunderbirde potom importujte tieto kontakty z tohoto *.csv súboru:

POZOR: - všetky tieto kopírovania a premenovania sa musia vykonávať pri ukončenom (vypnutom) Thunderbirde !!! = Import kontaktov je aj jednoduchší v prípade, že máte ešte prístup k starému Thunderbirdu so starým profilom. V starom Thunderbirde: Thunderbird - Nástroje - Adresár - Nástroje - EXPORT - a vytvoriť si súbor *.ldif a potom v novom Thunderbirde Thunderbird - Nástroje - Adresár - Nástroje - IMPORT - Adresáre a tu mu ponúknuť ten vytvorený *.ldif súbor.
creator: Ansamb

content:
If the target for drafts is Other: Drafts on Gmail, in Account Settings, Copies & Folders, where Drafts is under [Gmail], then Drafts appears as a purple icon in the Folder Pane, if it is subscribed. If you select just Drafts on Gmail, a second Drafts folder appears. This second folder is in the Subscribe list at the same level as Inbox (right-click the account in the Folder Pane, Subscribe...).

I recommend unsubscribing the second Drafts (and not selecting it as the target), since the one under [Gmail] is the same as Drafts in the webmail version. You'll have to do a test, but I think that is probably the same drafts folder used on the phone.

content:
I have the same folder display in webmail. When I compose a message in webmail then Save and close it, it's stored in the Drafts folder that is between Sent and All Mail. This draft also appears in TB in the Drafts folder that is shown in the first picture in my first reply. If I save a draft in TB, it appears in the webmail Drafts folder. So, to have a single Drafts folder in TB that syncs with the webmail Drafts, subscribe to Drafts as in my 2nd picture and unsubscribe the other Drafts in my 3rd picture. The picture attached to this post shows what you should have in Copies & Folders.

This unnecessary complexity is similar to the sent mail setup: messages sent from TB are automatically copied to Sent Mail, and they appear in webmail in Sent. There is no Sent Mail in webmail, and Sent Items is irrelevant.

Do a test by saving a draft on the phone, then check TB and webmail to see where it's saved.
creator: sfhowes

content:
On TB, I have changed by Drafts folders to "Other". However, the 'menus' to do so don't look anything like your 1st picture above. Once I click on the small triangle on the right side of the box which is immediately to the right of the word "Other", I have two choices: [xxxx@gmail.com] or [Local Folders}. When I chose the email address (even I can figure out that "Local Folders" is not the right pick), it brings up all the folders I have in my gmail account, so I selected "Drafts". Is that correct? So, now my Drafts folder is selected as "Other" and in the box is my gmail address.

As for your second and third pictures, I'm assuming that is on the web-based gmail site. However, I could not find anything like that on the site. Under "settings", "labels", I have something which lists all of my folders and there are two Drafts folders there. I have attached two screenshots which show this. I'm still unclear as how to "subscribe to Drafts as in my 2nd picture and unsubscribe the other Drafts in my 3rd picture".

Thanks for your help.
creator: queenmab100

content:
Queenmab100 said
On TB, I have changed by Drafts folders to "Other". However, the 'menus' to do so don't look anything like your 1st picture above. Once I click on the small triangle on the right side of the box which is immediately to the right of the word "Other", I have two choices: [xxxx@gmail.com] or [Local Folders}. When I chose the email address (even I can figure out that "Local Folders" is not the right pick), it brings up all the folders I have in my gmail account, so I selected "Drafts". Is that correct? So, now my Drafts folder is selected as "Other" and in the box is my gmail address.

Yes, in your case Other should point to Drafts on xxxx@gmail.com if the Account Name is the address. In my case, the Account Name, which is arbitrary, is Gmail.

As for your second and third pictures, I'm assuming that is on the web-based gmail site. However, I could not find anything like that on the site. Under "settings", "labels", I have something which lists all of my folders and there are two Drafts folders there. I have attached two screenshots which show this. I'm still unclear as how to "subscribe to Drafts as in my 2nd picture and unsubscribe the other Drafts in my 3rd picture". Thanks for your help.

The 2nd and 3rd pictures are the windows that show in TB when you right-click the account in the Folder Pane, Subscribe... You don't need to make any changes in webmail.
creator: sfhowes

content: Voila - that worked! No have only one Drafts folder and both the Iphone and the Mac save to that one folder. Thanks for your help!

You said "I checked and the files are there but they are not accessible via Thunderbird". Have you done this in the profile folders? Or do you mean that the headers are visible in the main interface but the bodies aren't?

creator: frisée

content: You would not lose your folders, as an uninstall leaves the profile intact, but that should not be necessary. If the account is refusing the password, you might try removing the old password. You can do that by clicking settings, then privacy&security, then click savedpasswords and then showpasswords and the highlight the rows for the account and delete them. That would give the opportunity usually to be prompted for new password.

creator: sfhowes

content:
All the users I look over have regular weekly backups that they do to external hard drives to offset this sort of thing. We've recovered their user data on more than a couple of occasions when either the hardware has let go or software has mangled important information.

It's a bit late now - obviously - but us old folks grew up keeping control of and securing their important data so we aren't caught as unprepared for this sort of thing.

For your own peace of mind, please make back ups of your important data. One OS glitch and you could lose everything.
creator: frisée

content:
Junk is sometimes labelled as such by the server at which they are first received. TB may only be following the labelling that is being received. Have you checked how the online account has marked the emails?

Have you been marking emails designated 'junk' as 'not junk'? If you are, does the same sender have their emails marked again as 'junk' the next time a message is received?
creator: frisée

content: Thanks for your reply. My server does mark them, and I don't have any problem with that showing up in Thunderbird. In fact, that is quite useful. The problem I'm having is that Thunderbird moves them to my junk folder, even though I set it to not do that. I had it set to move them before, but it was more annoying to have to check the junk folder, because it seems no amount of training (months of it) got it to recognize things properly. All I want is for it to stop moving the mail. Have I missed a setting? In the main Settings > Privacy & Security > Junk, I only have "Mark messages as read: When manually marked as junk" checked. The other settings are not checked and greyed out. In each account, in Account Settings > Junk Settings, everything is unchecked and greyed out. Any thoughts?

jqheywood said

But some allocations do seem strange. It's not a hassle for me as I don't get many emails but I can see it's a problem for you.

I don't think it's a setting (but what do I know?), it's just a querk.
creator: frisée

content:
Hi I have the same problem & have raised the question here.

For all the many years that I've used TB, I've never had junk mail going to a junk folder. This is how I want TB to work. I prefer to have ALL mail go to my global, combined, inbox & decide from there whether I need to reply/delete/forward etc. each email. This set up meant that I never missed an email through it being in the wrong folder.

Suddenly (just this year) I have had emails marked as junk go into a junk folder(s). Quite often, as today, I looked at my folder pane & there are no messages showing in junk. However, when clicking on that folder, I discovered that there were actually several emails there, some of them quite important

So, currently TB is deciding, quite randomly it would seem, that some emails are junk, but NOT showing them as unread emails in the junk folder in the folder pane

For each of my email accounts (I have several) I have the exact same settings that I've always had: Selection - nothing ticked Trust junk mail... not ticked Destination & retention - not ticked Global junk preferences - not ticked In some of the above, there is a "greyed out" blue button, but as the "master" entry isn't ticked/selected, then that is not of relevance

I have one email account with the exact same settings that doesn't put stuff into junk. The only difference with that account is that all emails to that address are filtered to a different folder on arrival

Even more frustratingly, today I've discovered that in my "junk" folder, I now have 2 or even 3 folders for each email address. It's all getting very strange & I have to say, quite frustrating

Any ideas??

Thanks
creator: debskinner21

content:
I am getting stopped, dead cold, every time I try to install Thunderbird mail on Linux Mint 22.

Please explain in detail

  • what you're doing,
  • what happens, and
  • what you expect to happen.
creator: christ1

content:
When the last screen in TB setup tries to open a connection with my Internet provider (Comcast/Xfinity), the trigger point is activated and the "Denied" pop up is displayed. At that moment I am locked out and must restart the TB installation from scratch.

If you haven't read through the link I included (I don't think you have!) about a deep dive into this long-standing error, you're not going to uderstand why this error is not to be associated with user setup', or their outstanding Linux configuration. There is nothing for me to find on my system because the problem occcurs before I am logged in. Akomai Security service is a large-entity security provider for commercial and government sites...Mozilla/Thunderbird is included among hundreds more. All of those entities are reporting similar issues involving their customer's experience trying to access their protected sites.

I've worked my way through these typical solutions:

  • Incorrect file permissions
  • Running TB as administrator
  • Firewall blocking access
  • Incorrect email account settings
  • Double-checked credentials
  • Checked Server settings
  • Checked my profile
  • Reviewed system logs

I stopped looking when I read about the issue online at the URL I sent with my initial message.

Thunderbird (the app) does not provide any log information that I can use, because it has never finished an install.

I want to use Thunderbird, but at this time there is no way to complete a full setup. This issue will NEVER be resolved by would be users...like me.

Thanks. Wiley Oregon, USA
creator: mwileym

content:

Again, thank you so much. Have a good week.

Wiley Miller Oregon, USA
